com.tacticalenterprisesltd

Class Join

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tacticalenterprisesltd.Join

  • public class Join
extends java.lang.Object
    The Join class is used to include additional fields from another database table to the main parent table for display in DataTables. The Join class performs its own database lookups based on the information you provide it. Minimally, it requires the name of the parent table and its Primary Key field. Optionally, you can specify a Join.Type. By default, this class uses a Type.STRAIGHT, which returns an empty String. Other Type options are: LEFT, RIGHT, INNER, OUTER, LEFT OUTER, RIGHT OUTER. Use the enum options to access these types. Optionally, you can also affect the condition on the JOIN statement by setting a different operator on the condition. By default the equals operator is used, but you can change it to <,>,<=,>=, etc. These options provide flexibility for convenience, however, depending on your requirements the results of any query can be unknown. You can try them at your own risk!
    In general, the Join syntax follows this pattern as part of an SQL SELECT statement:
    Type.STRAIGHT + " JOIN " + childTableName + " ON " + parentTableName + "." + parentField + conditionOperator + childTableName + "." + childField + " ";

    If using an alias for the childTable, be sure to provide the alias name as the first parameter in the constructor for the Field instance rather than the actual table name.

    Usage Example:

    //Parent table Primary Key
    String pKey = "ID";
    String[] tableNames = new String[]{"employees"};
    String[] fields = new String[]{"LASTNAME","FIRSTNAME","MOBILE_NUMBER","TYPE","HID","NAME"};
    ...
    Editor editor = new Editor(db, tableNames, pKey, params);
    Join join1 = new Join(editor,tableNames[0], "mobile");
    Field field2 = new Field("mobile",fields[2], Field.Type.STRING);
    Field field3 = new Field("mobile",fields[3], Field.Type.STRING);
    //Set a validator on the fields here if needed
    join1.addField(field2);
    join1.addField(field3);
    join1.setJoin(pKey,"EMPLOYEE_ID");
    editor.addJoin(join1);


    There are times when you want to have on the client side a drop down list of options or a set of checkboxes in your forms. That being the case, then there is a way to obtain an array of options.

    //Join the hobbies table with the employees table
    Join join2 = new Join(editor,tableNames[0],"hobbies");
    //The fields in table hobbies are read only. Table hobbies is just a lookup table.
    //Therefore, we set its fields so you can't write to them.
    Field field4 = new Field("hobbies",fields[4],Field.Type.INT);
    field4.setWrite(false);
    Field field5 = new Field("hobbies",fields[5],Field.Type.STRING);
    field5.setWrite(false);
    join2.addField(field4);
    join2.addField(field5);
    //If any inserts or updates are done, they will be done on the link table named hobbylink, not on the lookup table named hobbies.
    join2.setJoin(new String[]{pKey,"EMPLOYEE_ID"}, new String[]{"HID","HOBBY_ID"}, "hobbylink");
    editor.addJoin(join2);
    Version:
    1.5.0
    Author:
    Alan Shiers

      • setJoin

        public void setJoin(java.lang.String parentField,
           java.lang.String childField)
        Set the parameters required to complete the JOIN portion of the SELECT query. Use this method when you simply want to set an Object whereby you have a direct ONE-TO-ONE relationship between the parent table and the child table in the database.
        Parameters:
        parentField -
        childField -

      • setLinkJoin

        public void setLinkJoin(java.lang.String[] parentFields,
               java.lang.String[] childFields,
               java.lang.String link_table)
        Set the parameters required to complete the JOIN portion of the SELECT query. Use this method when you want to set an Array of options whereby you have a third LINK TABLE between the parent and child tables. This type of relationship generally denotes a ONE-T0-MANY relationship in a database. The Array it produces usually signifies any number of options provided for a drop-down select box or a set of checkboxes or radio buttons on the client side interface.
        Parameters:
        parentFields -
        childFields -
        link_table -
